Question_1.Context: The study developed a method for quantifying ACPA in biological samples. The method was validated for various parameters.
Question_1.Question: What was the linear concentration range for quantification of ACPA in the developed LC–MS/MS method?
Question_1.Source: The LC–MS/MS method showed an acceptable linearity range from 1.8 to 1000 ng/ml for ACPA.

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the sensitivity of the developed method for ACPA quantification.
Question_2.Question: What was the limit of detection (LOD) for ACPA in the LC–MS/MS method?
Question_2.Source: The LOD was 0.6 ng/ml, and the LOQ calculated in this work was 1.8 ng/ml with acceptable accuracy and precision.

Question_3.Context: The study assessed the matrix effect on the ionization of analytes in the developed method.
Question_3.Question: What was the matrix effect for ACPA in the presence of the sample matrix?
Question_3.Source: The matrix effect was calculated as 98.60% ± 1.67 for ACPA and 100.49% ± 1.60 for IS.

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the carryover effect in the developed LC–MS/MS method.
Question_4.Question: Was carryover observed in the blank matrix samples after the highest calibration standard injection?
Question_4.Source: The carryover was not observed in any of the blank matrix samples after the highest calibration standard injection.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the dilution integrity of the developed method.
Question_5.Question: What was the bias observed for the fivefold and tenfold dilution integrity tests?
Question_5.Source: The low bias (≤ 1.70%) and CV (≤ 1.40%) values were within acceptance criteria.

Question_6.Context: The study evaluated the precision and accuracy of the developed method.
Question_6.Question: What was the coefficient of variation (CV) for the inter-day precision at a concentration of 250 ng/mL?
Question_6.Source: The values (mean ± SE; n = 6) of the slope and intercept were 0.0021 ± 0.0001 and 0.0102 ± 0.0029, respectively.

Question_7.Context: The study assessed the robustness of the developed LC–MS/MS method.
Question_7.Question: What was the p value for the percentage of FA in mobile phase A in the robustness study?
Question_7.Source: The p values of each variable were higher than 0.05 indicating that small changes do not have a statistically significant effect on the peak area ratio and robustness of the method.

Question_8.Context: The study investigated the ruggedness of the developed method.
Question_8.Question: Was there a statistically significant difference between the results of two different analysts in the ruggedness study?
Question_8.Source: It was found that there was no statistically significant difference (p > 0.05) between them.

Question_9.Context: The study applied the developed method to quantify ACPA in cell culture samples.
Question_9.Question: What was the amount of ACPA found in the intracellular matrix after 24 hours of incubation?
Question_9.Source: The amount of ACPA in the intracellular matrix was found 773 ± 46.17 ng/ml after 24 h incubation.

Question_10.Context: The study concluded the applicability of the developed method for ACPA quantification.
Question_10.Question: What was the main recommendation regarding the use of the LC–MS/MS method?
Question_10.A: Use for drug development studies only
Question_10.C: Use for monitoring ACPA in different biological matrices
Question_10.Source: As a result, it can be recommended to use the LC–MS/MS method for monitoring of ACPA in drug development studies and pharmacokinetic studies to be performed in different biological matrices.
